title: Vision Changes In MS: What Does That Look Like?

content: Vision problems are common in people with multiple sclerosis. The cause could be the damage on the optic nerve or the effect that MS has on the brain. Some vision problems could be related to your MS treatment as well.

Sometimes it can get confusing to figure out if your eyesight problems are due to MS or if you are just aging. We all know that once you turn 40, your vision starts to change. It's common to have blurry vision or to need reading glasses to read the small print on the back of a medicine bottle or on a form, for example.
When you lose the ability to coordinate your eyes’ movement with the rotation of your head, it causes oscillopsia – objects look like they're jerking or wiggling.

Very often, patients get diagnosed with MS after an episode of optic neuritis, which is caused by inflammation of the optic nerve. With optic neuritis there could be changes in the perception of color, eye pain, blurry vision, or even vision loss.

content: INO (internuclear ophthalmoplegia) -- a lesion within the brain stem that disrupts the perfectly synchronized movement of your eyes, causing nystagmus (repetitive involuntary eye movements) or diplopia (double vision) -- is commonly the cause of these sight disturbances.

Nystagmus could interfere with your balance and coordination. The erratic movement of the eyes could occur up and down, side to side, or in a circular pattern. An ophthalmologist or a neurologist could diagnose it by looking at the eyes and noticing the spontaneous movement of them.

Antiseizure medications used in MS could cause nystagmus, although it’s not that common. You could feel dizzy or sensitive to bright light, and sometimes symptoms could worsen if you are tired or exposed to heat.

As far as treatment, if it’s due to a big flare-up, it usually resolves on its own once the flare-up ends and no intervention is necessary. If it’s permanent, then there are many medications to treat it. It could be a long road to recovery where surgery is used as a last resort.

content: When it comes to diplopia (double vision caused by misalignment of the eye), first the doctor has to determine where the misalignment is and then proceed to treat it. A round of steroids is commonly used, as well as prisms, a device that bends light, that is placed on glasses to correct the double vision.

Now, in real MS lingo, problems with your vision are the last thing you could wish for. Vision plays a significant role in balance. I mean, can you imagine? If you’re dizzy or have vertigo due to vision problems, and then you add mobility issues, what’s that going to be like? A calamity!

It’s so unfair that we have to deal with all these issues because of MS. I, knock on wood, have been lucky so far to not have experienced optic neuritis, diplopia, or nystagmus. But one of the first things I noticed after my first big flare-up was signs of oscillopsia. I remember describing it to my doctor as watching a movie through one of those old projectors they used in school, switching from slide to slide, and noticing like the images were jumpy. He said it was a very good way of describing it.

content: Throughout my journey I’ve met MSers that unfortunately have been struggling with eye issues for quite a while. Some that have had optic neuritis described it as eye pain at first, then being very sensitive to light, and then their vision turned black. They couldn’t see out of one eye.

Others mentioned that after recovering, they were left with what they described as “looking through a film” that was covering their eye. I’ve also seen others that choose to wear a fashionable eye patch on days of exacerbation.

There are some patients that sadly had to stop driving or that can’t live by themselves anymore. Their vision problems have changed the narrative of their daily life and had detrimental effects on the outcome of their story.

I’ve noticed a slight change in my vision, but it all started after I turned 40. So I’m not sure if it’s multiple sclerosis or I’m just getting old. I have blurred vision and need to wear reading glasses at this point. Hence the clarification that I never wore glasses before.

content: I definitely struggle with eye pain when I don’t sleep well or when I get overwhelmed, whether it’s by the noise, the light, or just sensory overload. I’ve mentioned in other blogs that I get this sudden poke on the corner of my eye that completely throws me off, and my eye closes immediately and starts tearing in agony. It’s not fun.
If you go to an MS-specialized neurologist, it’s common for them to examine your eyes in the office or send you out to get your eyes checked for damage or changes in your vision.

In case your neurologist doesn’t do that, ask for it or go to an eyeglasses shop where they will dilate your pupils and check your eyes as part of the routine exam. They’ll let you know if they find something unusual.
MS affects the optic nerve and causes vision changes, so it’s very important to check your eyes every year and to inform your neurologist if you notice any changes.

content: Remember, don’t wait for things to “come up” during your appointment and ALWAYS BE YOUR BEST ADVOCATE.
